item.title: Fortnite's Chapter 7 Launch Reportedly Propelled The Game To 3 Million Concurrent Players
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

It should be of little surprise that Fortnite is still doing really well, with its new Hollywood-themed first season of Chapter 7 reportedly drawing in a peak of around 3 million concurrent players at its launch.

The reported figure comes from prolific Fortnite leaker Shiina, who shared the number in an X post on Sunday. The new season, subtitled "Pacific Break," began Saturday, bringing a completely different battle royale map, along with new weapons and a battle pass.

This comes off the tail end of the Chapter 6 "Zero Hour" finale, which attracted 10.5 million players in-game and over 3 million viewers through livestreaming, according to Epic Games. The publisher unironically shared the Martin Scorsese "cinema" meme in celebration of these figures.

For those who missed it, Zero Hour was a colossal crossover event featuring an obscene number of IP, including Godzilla, Homer Simpson, King Kong, and the Power Rangers--almost enough to make Ready Player One look timid in comparison.

While these figures are undoubtedly impressive for any modern online video game, Fortnite is still falling short of its own all-time records. Attractions like The Simpsons mini-season lead to boosts in player count, but even the massive Zero Hour event had a lower player-count than last year's record shattering Remix Finale, which featured the likes of Eminem and Snoop Dogg--that event pulled in 14 million concurrent players.

Even still, most online games would be happy to have the numbers that Fortnite currently has. There are still plenty of reasons to jump (or surf, in the case of this season) into the battle royale, including the chance to see a long-lost chapter of Quentin Tarantino's Kill Bill, though accusations of AI-generated content in Chapter 7 have also been levied against Epic.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: The Hitman Franchise Will Continue, IO Interactive Confirms
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

What's next for the Hitman franchise? Developer IO Interactive isn't spilling the beans on its future plans for Agent 47, but the studio has confirmed that Hitman 3--now known as Hitman: World of Assassination following a 2023 rebranding--won't be the final entry in the franchise. In a new interview, IO Interactive CEO Hakan Abrak stated that news on the series will be revealed in due time, alongside details on the upcoming co-op mode for World of Assassination.

"Of course, there will be more Hitman," Abrak said to Variety. "But right now, I think we need to get to the other side of this year, and next year you'll get more news about Hitman co-op, because I think co-op is a really, really good extension to the universe and will introduce very interesting mechanics and combinations in World of Assassination. But we will after that be talking about the next Hitman--because, of course, there’s going to be a next Hitman."

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: How IO Interactive Is Making James Bond Different From Hitman

IO Interactive's upcoming James Bond game--007: First Light--launches in March 2026. Hitman: World of Assassination has received substantial post-launch support while the studio worked on its 007 game, with the most recent being a new Elusive Target mission that teams Agent 47 up with Eminem to kill the rapper's dangerous alter ego, Slim Shady. Senior level designer Håkan Almer and writer Jen Simpkins added that the mission will involve Eminem serving as a source of intel alongside Agent 47's handler, Diane Burnwood.

A third project, a multiplayer game under the working title Project Fantasy, is also in the works at IO Interactive. The game hasn't been formally revealed yet, but Abrak described it as an "extremely ambitious" effort from IO Interactive.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: This Scary The Game Awards Teaser Could Be For The Next Diablo 4 Expansion
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The Game Awards are coming up soon, and now host and organizer Geoff Keighley is hyping the event with some kind of real-world teaser campaign for something people believe is connected to Diablo.

On November 28, Keighley posted the tex "regal.inspiring.thickness" along with an image of some kind of huge carving featuring humanoid people in the middle of a desert. On November 29, Keighley followed up with a Google Maps image showing the location of the marketing monolith in the California desert. People quickly found the spot and posted images and video, including the ones below.

Windows Central reporter Jez Corden said the teaser is related to an upcoming Diablo 4 expansion announcement, "but also, more."

It was previously confirmed that Diablo 4 will get a new expansion in 2026, so a reveal at The Game Awards would make sense. The imagery of the teaser monolith is hellish as well, which is fitting if it's a Diablo 4 teaser.

Diablo 4 launched in June 2023 and received its first expansion, Vessel of Hatred, in October 2024. This added a new region and class, along with more loot and endgame content.

The Game Awards take place on Thursday, December 11, and we're expecting lots of news and reveals. Of course, the show will also hand out the awards themselves, including Game of the Year. For more, check out the gallery below in which he go through the biggest snubs.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Players Think They've Found AI Use In Fortnite Chapter 7, But Artist Shows It's Not Cut And Dried
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The debate over using generative AI art in media such as television show intros and background art in games has escalated over the past few years. A number of players have recently accused Epic Games of using generative AI for art in Fortnite, but things may be less easy to spot than some of them thought.

In the wake of Epic's CEO thinking that AI labeling should be done away with, fans pointed out a few alleged instances in Chapter 7. There's a poster for the Mile High Retreat, showing a Yeti napping in a hammock with the caption "relax faster, relax higher." Looking closer, though, the Yeti appears to have four toes on one foot and five toes on the other. Misnumbered digits are usually an indicator that something was AI-generated.

"So I'm pretty much done with Fortnite," one player posted on Bluesky. "There were statements made by Tim Sweeney saying that AI usage doesn't need to be disclosed, and then AI usage was found all over this current season, from art to sprays to in-game songs." They posted three more instances of AI usage; however, one of them was proven to have been done by a human artist.

"I don’t have a Reddit account, but just in case people are being weird, here’s my Procreate layers," said artist Sean Dove, who has been a professional illustrator for over a decade. With artists getting caught in the crossfire of accusations, the situation is more harmful than it needs to be.

"IMO judging off of speculation like this is disrespectful when you can't be 100% sure this isn't something an actual artist put effort into," one Reddit user posted on a thread discussing AI art. "Everyone's giving reasons that have nothing to do with the art besides the style or reasons that could pass as human imperfection."

Despite AI seemingly taking up more speace, not everyone is on board with the technology. Rockstar Games co-founder Dan Houser is dabbling with AI but thinks it's "overrated." The Witcher 3 director Konrad Tomaszkiewicz said games made exclusively with AI will be soulless. Even a US congressman is calling for regulations on AI after Black Ops 7 sparked a heated debate over its use.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com



https://www.gamespot.com/articles/players-think-theyve-found-ai-use-in-fortnite-chapter-7-but-artist-shows-its-not-cut-and-dried/1100-6536597/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

item.title: The Witcher 4 Still Has Two Sequels Planned Within Six Years, CD Projekt Red Asserts
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

There's still no release date or window for The Witcher 4. But that's not stopping CD Projekt Red from stating again that a whole new trilogy might launch within a six-year timespan. That's been the plan for years, but the company reasserted this position during a recent financial call, according to Eurogamer.

CD Projekt co-CEO Michal Nowakowski was asked about the company utilizing Unreal Engine 5 for The Witcher 4 and whether that could lead to shorter development cycles for future sequels. "In a way, yes, I do believe that further games should be delivered in a shorter period of time--as we had stated before, our plan still is to launch the whole trilogy within a six-year period, so yes, that would mean we would plan to have a shorter development time between [The Witcher 4] and [The Witcher] 5, between [The Witcher] 5 and [The Witcher] 6 and so on," Nowakowski said.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: The Witcher 4 - Unreal Engine 5 Tech Walkthrough | State Of Unreal 2025

Nowakowski's co-CEO at CD Projekt, Adam Kicinski, discussed this six-year timespan for the new Witcher trilogy in 2022--over three years ago. To be clear, the clock would start ticking on six years once The Witcher 4 launches, and that won't happen until 2027 at the earliest. If, for example, The Witcher 4 did come out then, that would mean CD Projekt aims for The Witcher 5 to hit in 2030 and The Witcher 6 in 2033.

The Witcher 4 entered "full-scale production" last year and then appeared at The Game Awards 2024 with a trailer. Earlier this year, CD Projekt Red showed off a tech demo of The Witcher 4 running on PS5. While it wasn't actual gameplay footage, the video saw Ciri standing on a cliff, riding a horse named Kelpie, and entering a port town called Valdrest. The Witcher 4 is actually being developed with consoles in mind first, a change from how Cyberpunk 2077 was developed.

Meanwhile, don't expect The Witcher 4 to show up at The Game Awards later this month.
